titleStmt.title: The Starting-Post; Or Clarkson at Woods-Mill
titleStmt.author: Bernard Barton

div.head: The Starting-Post; Or Clarkson at Woods-Mill

epigraph.ab: "Coming in sight of Wades-Mill, in Hertfordshire, I sat down disconsolate on the turf by the road-side, and held my horse. Here a thought came into my mind, that if the contents of the Essay were true, it was time some person should see these calamities to their end. Agitated in this manner, I reached home. This was in the summer of 1785." Clarkson's History of Abolition, Vol. I. p. 210.Thomas Clarkson's The History of the Abolition of the African Slave-Trade is a two-volume history of the first wave of efforts to abolish the slave trade in Great Britain. Full texts can be accessed at the Liberty Fund text archive.

lg.l: A wanderer by the road-way side,
Though rich the landscape, hill, and plain,
One hand holds fast his bridle-rein,
The flush of youth is on his brow,
Its fire is in his eye;
And yet the first is pensive now,
Prompt him Love's bliss to win?
His ear has caught the captive's groan,
Nor less from Afric's land afar,
The hideous din of sordid War,
The iron of that galling yoke
How shall Power's tyrant spell be broke?­
The sick at heart made whole?
Who, e'en on Albion's far-famed Isle,
Shall live but for her cause?
Who, the Apostle of her Creed,
"Thou art the man!" the Prophet cried;
And, while his heart with anguish sighed,
As clear, as vivid the appeal
And God himself hath set his seal,­
